I have Kallmann syndrome.

Kallmann syndrome is a condition in which puberty is blocked or stopped. Kallmann syndrome is a form of HH where there is no sense of smell.

I have had Kisspeptin injections on two occasions as part of clinical trials and I failed to respond both times as would be expected with people with Kallmann syndrome / CHH as we do not have the ability to release GnRH, the hormone that controls puberty and reproductive function.

Developmental processes tend to be "cascade"-type processes, that means that a bunch of factors undergoing their own evolutions spill over into causing another set of factors to do the same, but as co-factors and not on an individual basis.
That said, it is of interest at the same time to use this video as an opportunity to point out that the brain is unsexed and that the signal that kicks of puberty in this model is unsexed until it reaches the gonads. After that (and during development) the brain mediates and sometimes blocks the effect of sex-linked hormones on its own development (see blood-brain barrier, little known fact, it even mediates water). This all makes sense as gender-rolling occurs in the absence of hormone differences at around the age of 1.5-2.5y.o.

I can't believe I never heard about kisspeptin. I went through early puberty. Before intervention, I had my first period at age 9. And while this is anecdotal evidence, I'm disinclined to believe the hypothesis mentioned here that the metabolic changes that singal a body is at the right size for puberty is the triggering mechanism. Because I was small for a six year old when, unknowningly, puberty started for me. The entire reason I started on puberty blockers was because my bones were being bombarded with growth hormones, while my growth plates weren't yet ready, meaning all my naturally produced growth hormones weren't being used. Stopping puberty at menses wasn't the most effective, but it let me grab a few more inches. It didn't help that I would have always been short because my parents are both short.
